articles.headline: Qaeda Branch Steps Up Raids in North Africa
articles.snippet: Security experts fear Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb has turned a corner in becoming a greater security threat.
articles.abstract: Security experts fear Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb has turned a corner in becoming a greater security threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Al Qaeda’s affiliate in North Africa has carried out a string of killings, bombings and other lethal attacks against Westerners and African security forces in recent weeks that have raised fears that the terrorist group may be taking a deadlier turn.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: A Muscle Car to the Rescue
articles.snippet: G.M.’s new Camaro, a throwback to another era, is creating a buzz in otherwise quiet showrooms.
articles.abstract: G.M.’s new Camaro, a throwback to another era, is creating a buzz in otherwise quiet showrooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Believe it or not, General Motors has a hit car on its hands.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: At Beazer Homes, It Was See No Evil and Pay No Penalty
articles.snippet: Beazer Homes USA, a home builder, settled its legal crimes, but its top officials remain with the company.
articles.abstract: Beazer Homes USA, a home builder, settled its legal crimes, but its top officials remain with the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Beazer Homes USA was much more than a builder of houses. It was a veritable crime wave.

articles.headline: UBS Digs in Its Heels on Clients’ Names
articles.snippet: The chief of the bank said in a memorandum that it would not comply with the I.R.S. because doing so would violate Swiss law.
articles.abstract: The chief of the bank said in a memorandum that it would not comply with the I.R.S. because doing so would violate Swiss law.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Swiss bank UBS and federal prosecutors face off in a Florida courtroom on Monday, the focus will be whether UBS must disclose the identities of thousands of its American clients, but much more could be at stake as well.

articles.headline: Citigroup Shuffles Top Ranks Again
articles.snippet: Citigroup made is third change in top management in less than a year, a move that recognized regulators’ concerns.
articles.abstract: Citigroup made is third change in top management in less than a year, a move that recognized regulators’ concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Edward J. Kelly had been diligently preparing to be the voice of Citigroup on the bank’s earnings call with investors next Friday, his second in the four brief months since abruptly taking over as chief financial officer.

articles.headline: Kurds Defy Baghdad, Laying Claim to Land and Oil
articles.snippet: With little notice, Kurdistan is moving forward on a new constitution, alarming some Iraqis and Americans.
articles.abstract: With little notice, Kurdistan is moving forward on a new constitution, alarming some Iraqis and Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  With little notice and almost no public debate, Iraq’s Kurdish leaders are pushing ahead with a new constitution for their semiautonomous region, a step that has alarmed Iraqi and American officials who fear that the move poses a new threat to the country’s unity.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Seeks U.S. Support for Bonuses
articles.snippet: The embattled insurer has been quietly seeking approval to pay $2.4 million in bonuses to its senior executives.
articles.abstract: The embattled insurer has been quietly seeking approval to pay $2.4 million in bonuses to its senior executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seeking to avoid the public furor that erupted last spring, the American International Group has been quietly seeking approval from the new federal compensation czar to pay a total of $2.4 million dollars in bonuses to dozens of its senior executives.

articles.headline: G.M. Vow to Slim Includes Top Ranks
articles.snippet: General Motors, which emerged from bankruptcy, must tackle its next thorny problem — its management team.
articles.abstract: General Motors, which emerged from bankruptcy, must tackle its next thorny problem — its management team.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors, which emerged from bankruptcy on Friday, now must tackle its next thorny problem  its own management team.
